!FilteringMMS

• Recipient Based Check. The limit is set to 20 for a minute. 

• Sender Based Check. The limit is set to 50 for a minute. 

• Combination of Recipient and Sender check.The limit is set to 20 per minute (This means if the same source is sending MMS to same recipient, only 20 MMS are allowed and 21st MMS will be blocked.) 

(My interpretation regarding the three rules above is that it's best to stay under 20 messages per minute from a Twilio number) 


Syniverse MMS Velocity Error:


The error 107-Spam-Sender Block-Dynamic is velocity based spamming block.

Hello _______,


Thank you for providing additional information. It looks like you are sending very high volume of MMS messages to end users using Twilio number _______ .


We have done testing internally for high volume MMS messages at Twilio and was also informed by our carrier, MMS messages may not be delivered when sent in high volume. Usually messages that surpass approximately 20 messages per minute will experience velocity/volume filtering for MMS messages (please note this number is an approximate as carriers can change this at anytime). To avoid velocity filtering, the key is to spread your MMS traffic over a wider range of time or distribute your traffic among various Twilio numbers. The key to avoid velocity filtering is to not send a burst of MMS messages per minute.


Please try out the above suggestions and let me know if you continue to experience undelivered MMS messages.


Thanks,

Dear _____, 


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear you are experiencing carrier filtering on your account. 


From our experience, there are two common reasons that will trigger this error. (1) When sending messages with similar or identical content from a long code within a short period time, mobile carriers are likely to block messages suspecting them to be spam. (2) Some keywords or message content can also trigger carrier filtering. I believe you are being filtered for both of these reasons or _______ .


You can read more about how carrier filtering works here: https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223181848-How-Does-Carrier-Filtering-Work-


I took a look at your activity the last 7 days. I see there is quite high volume on most of your Twilio numbers, most days you are sending over _____ messages per day. This is extremely high volume and usage for your Twilio numbers in a span of 7 days.


Below are suggestions to mitigate carrier filtering:


- Decrease volume from each of your Twilio numbers, try to send less than 15 messages from a Twilio number in a minute. Preferably, less than 200 messages from a Twilio number per day. The data shows us high volume on any single number can cause carrier filtering and distributing traffic can help mitigate carrier filtering. Please add additional Twilio numbers to distribute traffic.


- Send messages at a slower rate: https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223183648-Sending-and-Receiving-Limitations-on-Calls-and-SMS-Messages


- Consider using our Co-Pilot feature which helps you scale and distribute your traffic evenly among your Twilio numbers. Please note that Copilot will not however add more numbers to your Copilot when your traffic increases. Please monitor and add more numbers to Copilot in order for messages to be distributed evenly if your traffic increases:


https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/sending-messages-copilot#scaler  

 

-Have variety of content in your messages. Avoid using the same template in all your messages. Avoid marketing keywords.


- Consider using a short code. Short codes are not subject to carrier filtering. It is best used when sending high volume messages and having similar content in the body of your messages. Please let me know if you are interested to learn more about short codes and I can refer the Sales Team to provide further assistance and answer any questions you may have regarding short codes.


https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223182068-What-is-a-short-code- 


I understand this is a lot of information, please do not hesitate to contact me if you have any further questions or need any clarification.


Thanks,

Dear ______, 


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear you are experiencing undelivered messages. 


Thank you for providing the Message SID examples, I appreciate it. I further investigated into these message examples and it appears that your messages are being filtered by our carrier as spam due to the marketing related content in the messages. Keywords such as ______ are very likely to be marked as spam by carriers. 


May you please kindly retest by removing these marketing keywords and retry? Please note that carriers may put a block on the Twilio number for up to a few days, hence if you retry right away without the marketing keywords, the Twilio number may still potentially be blocked.


If this is urgent, consider provisioning new Twilio numbers to send messages. 


Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help. 


Warmest Regards,

**FilteringRules

Carrier Filtering Best Practices:


  • Please be aware of destination carrier filtering from Verizon, AT&T, Canadian Carriers (esp. Rogers network), Zipwhip (Twilio toll-free numbers)

  • Check for Macros in Zendesk for Verizon, AT&T, and Canadia

  • More information can be found in our Wiki below: https://wiki.hq.twilio.com/display/CSIKB/Carrier+Filtering


How to Check for Carrier Filtering using Looker:


  • Use 1: Message usage per DID in the past  7 days (useful to check if customers overwork their numbers and hence causing 30007 errors): https://reports-looker.twilio.com/looks/12055


  • Use 2: Breakdown of Errors on the Account (useful to check the number messages that are receiving 30007 errors): https://reports-looker.twilio.com/looks/12056


  • Use 3: Destination Carrier Delivery Analysis in Accounts (useful to see which destination carriers are filtering messages): https://reports-looker.twilio.com/looks/11930

!FilteringA2PP2P

Dear _____ ,


I will also advise to be mindful of your traffic if you are sending Application to Person (A2P) traffic over your Twilio long code numbers as long codes are meant for P2P communication and can potentially be filtered by destination carriers such as _______. Below I have provided information explaining the difference between A2P and P2P:


To help you understand the difference between A2P and P2P messages, A2P messages are  commonly defined as SMS messages that are sent from an application to a subscriber, typically for commercial purposes. For example, marketing messages, appointment reminders, activation codes, or updates sent from a web application to a subscriber would all be considered A2P. As a practical matter, any high-volume traffic involving the same or similar messages may be flagged as A2P traffic. In contrast, P2P messages are SMS messages exchanged between two mobile subscribers, such as a person sending an SMS to their friend or colleague.


Please let me know if you have further questions.


Thanks,
